For every prime number p in the natural numbers, the p-adic norm of the sum of two p-adic numbers is less than or equal to the maximum of their individual p-adic norms.

type: ‚àÄ {p : ‚Ñï} [hp : Fact p.Prime] (q r : ‚Ñö_[p]), ‚Äñq + r‚Äñ ‚â§ max ‚Äñq‚Äñ ‚Äñr‚Äñ
name: padicNormE.nonarchimedean
docString: For every prime number p in the natural numbers, the p-adic norm of the sum of two p-adic numbers is less than or equal to the maximum of their individual p-adic norms.

This theorem states that two positive natural numbers, `a` and `b`, are equal if and only if their p-adic valuations are equal for every prime number `p`. This means that for every prime number `p`, the highest power of `p` that divides `a` is the same as the highest power of `p` that divides `b`. Note that `a` and `b` must be non-zero for this theorem to apply.

type: ‚àÄ (a b : ‚Ñï), a ‚â† 0 ‚Üí b ‚â† 0 ‚Üí (a = b ‚Üî ‚àÄ (p : ‚Ñï), p.Prime ‚Üí padicValNat p a = padicValNat p b)
name: Nat.eq_iff_prime_padicValNat_eq
docString: This theorem states that two positive natural numbers, `a` and `b`, are equal if and only if their p-adic valuations are equal for every prime number `p`. This means that for every prime number `p`, the highest power of `p` that divides `a` is the same as the highest power of `p` that divides `b`. Note that `a` and `b` must be non-zero for this theorem to apply.

Two positive naturals are equal if their prime padic valuations are equal

type: ‚àÄ (a b : ‚Ñï), a ‚â† 0 ‚Üí b ‚â† 0 ‚Üí (a = b ‚Üî ‚àÄ (p : ‚Ñï), Nat.Prime p ‚Üí padicValNat p a = padicValNat p b)
name: Nat.eq_iff_prime_padicValNat_eq
docString: Two positive naturals are equal if their prime padic valuations are equal

For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

type: ‚àÄ (n : ‚Ñï), Even (n * (n - 1))
name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

This theorem, `Mathlib.Data.Int.Parity._auxLemma.19`, states that the integer 1 is not even. In the context of this theorem, a number is defined as even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers. However, there is no integer that, when doubled, equals 1, hence 1 is not considered even under this definition.

type: ‚àÄ {Œ± : Sort u_1} {a b : Œ±}, (a = b) = (b = a)
name: Mathlib.Data.Int.Parity._auxLemma.19

If the p-adic valuation of a finite set of positive rationals is greater than a given rational

name: padicValRat.lt_sum_of_lt
